conclusion: Objects A and B start moving in a straight line simultaneously and from the same location at rest.
The relationship between the acceleration of the objects and time is shown in the problem diagram, where t2 = 2t1.
The acceleration graph shows object A with constant acceleration a0 from 0 to t1.
The acceleration graph shows object B with linearly increasing acceleration from 0 to a0 at t1.

premise: The velocity of each object is the area under its a–t curve from 0 to t₁.
conclusion: For object A, the velocity v_A is the area of a rectangle with height a₀ and width t₁, so v_A = a₀ t₁.

premise: The velocity of each object is the area under its a–t curve from 0 to t₁.
conclusion: For object B, the velocity v_B is the area of a right-triangle with base t₁ and height a₀, so v_B = ½ a₀ t₁.

premise: v_A = a₀ t₁ and v_B = ½ a₀ t₁
conclusion: v_A = 2 v_B, hence the velocities are unequal at t₁.
